nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: It’s early morning. Your phone buzzes louder than your alarm. It’s a long message from your ex — written at 3:12 AM.

choices.label: Read the message immediately.
choices.text: You unlock your phone and open the message, heart already racing.

choices.label: Silence the phone and give yourself five minutes.
choices.text: You flip the phone over and focus on breathing. The message can wait a moment.

nodes.speaker: Ex-Partner
nodes.text: The message is a mix of panic and blame: “I can’t sleep, I’m doing EVERYTHING for our child. You don’t understand how hard this is. Maybe I should just keep her full time.”

choices.label: Reply with reassurance and boundaries.
choices.text: You type: “I hear that you’re overwhelmed. We’re both doing our best. Let’s talk about changes to the schedule with a mediator, not at 3 AM.”

choices.label: React defensively.
choices.text: You snap back: “You’re not the only one who’s tired. Threatening custody changes in the middle of the night is not okay.”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: You stare at the screen, thinking of your child still asleep, unaware of these late-night storms.

choices.label: Focus on what you can control today.
choices.text: You decide to anchor your day: breakfast, school drop-off, work. One step at a time.

choices.label: Spiral into worst-case scenarios.
choices.text: You imagine court battles, custody fights, the worst of everything, all before breakfast.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: The day is just beginning, but the emotional weather is already stormy.

choices.label: Move to Act 2 – Planning the Conversation.
choices.text: You decide this can’t stay in endless text threads. It needs structure.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: Later that day, you sit at the kitchen table with a notepad. You know that unstructured talks often end in chaos.

choices.label: Suggest meeting with a mediator.
choices.text: You draft: “I think it would help if we talked about schedules with a neutral mediator. Would you be open to that?”

choices.label: Try to handle it alone, one-on-one.
choices.text: You decide to invite them for coffee to “talk it out”, just the two of you.

nodes.speaker: Ex-Partner
nodes.text: Their reply pings back: “I don’t need a stranger telling me how to raise my kid.”

choices.label: Normalize support.
choices.text: You write: “Mediators aren’t there to judge, just to help us communicate when things feel intense.”

choices.label: Back off and postpone.
choices.text: You decide not to push it further today and let the topic rest.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: You remind yourself that bipolar disorder adds another layer to every conversation: energy spikes, crashes, and sensitivity to perceived criticism.

choices.label: Plan your next steps around stability, not reaction.
choices.text: You make a note to only suggest big changes during more stable periods, not right after crises.

choices.label: Continue to react to the latest mood.
choices.text: You resign yourself to “seeing how they are that day” and adjusting on the fly.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: You put the pen down. The situation is still complex, but at least you have a plan that doesn’t rely solely on midnight messages.
